md:py-[var(--s20)] px-[var(--s16)] md:px-[var(--s24)] bg-light3"><span class="block text-button flex-1">Try our demo</span><span class="block shrink-0"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="text-body"><span class="text-tertiary">How do we know when someone truly understands us? It is rarely just our words—it is in the subtleties of voice: the rising excitement, the thoughtful pause, the warm reassurance.<br/><br/>Voice is our most intimate medium as humans, carrying layers of meaning through countless variations in tone, pitch, rhythm, and emotion.<br/><br/>Today’s digital voice assistants lack essential qualities to make them truly useful. Without unlocking the full power of voice, they cannot hope to effectively collaborate with us. A personal assistant who speaks only in a neutral tone has difficulty finding a permanent place in our daily lives after the initial novelty wears off.<br/><br/>Over time this emotional flatness becomes more than just disappointing—it becomes exhausting.</span></p></div><div><h3 class="text-research-h2">Achieving voice presence</h3><p class="mt-[var(--s20)] text-body"><span class="text-tertiary">At Sesame, our goal is to achieve “voice presence”—the magical quality that makes spoken interactions feel real, understood, and valued. We are creating conversational partners that do not just process requests; they engage in genuine dialogue that builds confidence and trust over time. In doing so, we hope to realize the untapped potential of voice as the ultimate interface for instruction and understanding.</span></p></div><div><h3 class="text-research-h2">Key components</h3><div class="mt-[var(--s20)] text-body"><div class="text-tertiary"><ul class="pl-[var(--s16)]" style="list-style-type:disc"><li>Emotional intelligence: reading and responding to emotional contexts.</li><li>Conversational dynamics: natural timing, pauses, interruptions and emphasis.</li><li>Contextual awareness: adjusting tone and style to match the situation.</li><li>Consistent personality: maintaining a coherent, reliable and appropriate presence.</li></ul></div></div></div></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-0 md:gap-[var(--s46)]"><div><h3 class="text-research-h2">We’re not there yet </h3><p class="mt-[var(--s20)] text-body"><span class="text-tertiary">Building a digital companion with voice presence is not easy, but we are making steady progress on multiple fronts, including personality, memory, expressivity and appropriateness. This demo is a showcase of some of our work in conversational speech generation. The companions shown here have been optimized for friendliness and expressivity to illustrate the potential of our approach.</span></p><div id="demo"></div></div><div class="pt-[var(--s60)] id="technical"></div><div class="line"></div><div><p class="text-body text-tertiary pb-[var(--s8)]">Technical post</p><h1 class="text-research-h1 mb-[var(--s40)]"><span class="block md:inline">Conversational</span><span class="block md:inline"> speech generation</span></h1><div><div class="grid grid-cols-7 gap-[var(--s24)] sm:gap-[var(--s8)] gap-y-[var(--s24)] pb-[var(--s32)]"><div class="col-start-1 col-end-8 md:col-start-1 sm:col-end-5 lg:col-start-1 lg:col-end-6"><p class="text-body">Authors</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary"><span class="whitespace-nowrap">Johan Schalkwyk</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Ankit Kumar</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Dan Lyth</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Sefik Emre Eskimez</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Zack Hodari</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Cinjon Resnick</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Ramon Sanabria</span>,<!-- --> <span class="whitespace-nowrap">Raven Jiang</span></p></div></div></div><p class="text-body text-tertiary mt-[var(--s20)]">To create AI companions that feel genuinely interactive, speech generation must go beyond producing high-quality audio—it must understand and adapt to context in real time. Traditional text-to-speech (TTS) models generate spoken output directly from text but lack the contextual awareness needed for natural conversations. Even though recent models produce highly human-like speech, they struggle with the one-to-many problem: there are countless valid ways to speak a sentence, but only some fit a given setting. Without additional context—including tone, rhythm, and history of the conversation—models lack the information to choose the best option. Capturing these nuances requires reasoning across multiple aspects of language and prosody.<br/><br/>To address this, we introduce the Conversational Speech Model (CSM), which frames the problem as an end-to-end multimodal learning task using transformers. It leverages the history of the conversation to produce more natural and coherent speech. There are two key takeaways from our work. The first is that CSM operates as a <span class="text-main">single-stage model</span>, thereby improving efficiency and expressivity. The second is our <span class="text-main">evaluation suite</span>, which is necessary for evaluating progress on contextual capabilities and addresses the fact that common public evaluations are saturated.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Background</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">One approach to modeling audio with transformers is to convert continuous waveforms into discrete audio token sequences using tokenizers. Most contemporary approaches (<a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.12925">[1]</a>,<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.03312">[2]</a>) rely on two types of audio tokens:</p><ol class="text-body text-tertiary list-decimal pl-[var(--s24)]"><li><span class="text-main">Semantic tokens</span>: Compact speaker-invariant representations of semantic and phonetic features. Their compressed nature enables them to capture key speech characteristics at the cost of high-fidelity representation.</li><li><span class="text-main">Acoustic tokens</span>: Encodings of fine-grained acoustic details that enable high-fidelity audio reconstruction. These tokens are often generated using Residual Vector Quantization (RVQ)<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.03312">[2]</a>. In contrast to semantic tokens, acoustic tokens retain natural speech characteristics like speaker-specific identity and timbre.</li></ol><p class="text-body text-tertiary">A common strategy first models semantic tokens and then generates audio using RVQ or diffusion-based methods. Decoupling these steps allows for a more structured approach to speech synthesis—the semantic tokens provide a compact, speaker-invariant representation that captures high-level linguistic and prosodic information, while the second-stage reconstructs the fine-grained acoustic details needed for high-fidelity speech. However, this approach has a critical limitation; semantic tokens are a bottleneck that must fully capture prosody, but ensuring this during training is challenging.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">RVQ-based methods introduce their own set of challenges. Models must account for the sequential dependency between codebooks in a frame. One method, the delay pattern (figure below)<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2306.05284">[3]</a>, shifts higher codebooks progressively to condition predictions on lower codebooks within the same frame. A key limitation of this approach is that the time-to-first-audio scales poorly because an RVQ tokenizer with N codebooks requires N backbone steps before decoding the first audio chunk. While suitable for offline applications like audiobooks, this delay is problematic in a real-time scenario.</p><div class="w-full overflow-hidden rounded-radius2 relative"><div class="w-full relative" style="background-color:white;aspect-ratio:624/448" data-sentry-component="Image" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx"><img alt="Example of delayed pattern generation in an RVQ tokenizer with 4 codebooks" data-sentry-element="NextImage" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" class="w-full h-full object-cover transition-opacity duration-300" style="position:absolute;height:100%;width:100%;left:0;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;color:transparent;opacity:0" sizes="100vw" srcSet="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=128&amp;q=75 128w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=256&amp;q=75 256w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=512&amp;q=75 512w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=1024&amp;q=75 1024w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=1536&amp;q=75 1536w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=2048&amp;q=75 2048w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=3072&amp;q=75 3072w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75 4096w" src="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsequence.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75"/></div></div><p class="text-caption-sm text-tertiary px-[var(--s24)]">Example of delayed pattern generation in an RVQ tokenizer with 4 codebooks</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Conversational Speech Model</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">CSM is a multimodal, text and speech model that operates directly on RVQ tokens. Inspired by the RQ-Transformer<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.01941">[4]</a>, we use two autoregressive transformers. Different from the approach in<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.00037">[5]</a>, we split the transformers at the zeroth codebook. The first<span class="text-main"> multimodal backbone</span> processes interleaved text and audio to model the zeroth codebook. The second <span class="text-main">audio decoder</span> uses a distinct linear head for each codebook and models the remaining N – 1 codebooks to reconstruct speech from the backbone’s representations. The decoder is significantly smaller than the backbone, enabling low-latency generation while keeping the model end-to-end.</p><div class="w-full overflow-hidden rounded-radius2 relative"><div class="w-full relative" style="background-color:white;aspect-ratio:624/487" data-sentry-component="Image" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx"><img alt="CSM model inference process" data-sentry-element="NextImage" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" class="w-full h-full object-cover transition-opacity duration-300" style="position:absolute;height:100%;width:100%;left:0;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;color:transparent;opacity:0" sizes="100vw" srcSet="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=128&amp;q=75 128w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=256&amp;q=75 256w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=512&amp;q=75 512w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=1024&amp;q=75 1024w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=1536&amp;q=75 1536w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=2048&amp;q=75 2048w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=3072&amp;q=75 3072w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75 4096w" src="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Farchitecture.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75"/></div></div><p class="text-caption-sm text-tertiary px-[var(--s24)]">CSM model inference process. Text (T) and audio (A) tokens are interleaved and fed sequentially into the Backbone, which predicts the zeroth level of the codebook. The Decoder then samples levels 1 through N – 1 conditioned on the predicted zeroth level. The reconstructed audio token (A) is then autoregressively fed back into the Backbone for the next step, continuing until the audio EOT symbol is emitted. This process begins again on the next inference request, with the interim audio (such as a user utterance) being represented by interleaved audio and text transcription tokens.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">Both transformers are variants of the Llama architecture. Text tokens are generated via a Llama tokenizer<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2407.21783">[6]</a>, while audio is processed using Mimi, a split-RVQ tokenizer, producing one semantic codebook and N – 1 acoustic codebooks per frame at 12.5 Hz.<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.00037">[5]</a> <!-- -->Training samples are structured as alternating interleaved patterns of text and audio, with speaker identity encoded directly in the text representation.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Compute amortization</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">This design introduces significant infrastructure challenges during training. The audio decoder processes an effective batch size of B × S and N codebooks autoregressively, where B is the original batch size, S is the sequence length, and N is the number of RVQ codebook levels. This high memory burden even with a small model slows down training, limits model scaling, and hinders rapid experimentation, all of which are crucial for performance.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">To address these challenges, we use a compute amortization scheme that alleviates the memory bottleneck while preserving the fidelity of the full RVQ codebooks. The audio decoder is trained on only a random 1/16 subset of the audio frames, while the zeroth codebook is trained on every frame. We observe no perceivable difference in audio decoder losses during training when using this approach.</p><div class="w-full overflow-hidden rounded-radius2 relative"><div class="w-full relative" style="background-color:white;aspect-ratio:624/384" data-sentry-component="Image" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx"><img alt="Amortized training process" data-sentry-element="NextImage" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" class="w-full h-full object-cover transition-opacity duration-300" style="position:absolute;height:100%;width:100%;left:0;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;color:transparent;opacity:0" sizes="100vw" srcSet="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=128&amp;q=75 128w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=256&amp;q=75 256w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=512&amp;q=75 512w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=1024&amp;q=75 1024w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=1536&amp;q=75 1536w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=2048&amp;q=75 2048w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=3072&amp;q=75 3072w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75 4096w" src="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Famortization.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75"/></div></div><p class="text-caption-sm text-tertiary px-[var(--s24)]">Amortized training process. The backbone transformer models the zeroth level across all frames (highlighted in blue), while the decoder predicts the remaining N – 31 levels, but only for a random 1/16th of the frames (highlighted in green). The top section highlights the specific frames modeled by the decoder for which it receives loss.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Experiments</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary"><span class="text-main">Dataset</span>: We use a large dataset of publicly available audio, which we transcribe, diarize, and segment. After filtering, the dataset consists of approximately one million hours of predominantly English audio.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary"><span class="text-main">Model Sizes</span>: We trained three model sizes, delineated by the backbone and decoder sizes:</p><ul class="text-body text-tertiary list-disc pl-[var(--s24)]"><li><span class="text-main">Tiny</span>: 1B backbone, 100M decoder</li><li><span class="text-main">Small</span>: 3B backbone, 250M decoder</li><li><span class="text-main">Medium</span>: 8B backbone, 300M decoder</li></ul><p class="text-body text-tertiary">Each model was trained with a 2048 sequence length (~2 minutes of audio) over five epochs.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 audio prompts from two speakers</p><p></p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Evaluation</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">Our evaluation suite measures model performance across four key aspects: faithfulness to text, context utilization, prosody, and latency. We report both objective and subjective metrics—objective benchmarks include word error rate and novel tests like homograph disambiguation, while subjective evaluation relies on a Comparative Mean Opinion Score (CMOS) human study using the <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.05725">Expresso</a> <!-- -->dataset.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Objective metrics</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">Traditional benchmarks, such as word error rate (WER) and speaker similarity (SIM), have become saturated—modern models, including CSM, now achieve near-human performance on these metrics.</p><div class="w-full overflow-hidden rounded-radius2 relative"><div class="w-full relative" style="background-color:white;aspect-ratio:624/387" data-sentry-component="Image" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx"><img alt="Objective metric results for Word Error Rate and Speaker Similarity tests" data-sentry-element="NextImage" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" class="w-full h-full object-cover transition-opacity duration-300" src="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FWER%2BSS.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75"/></div></div><p class="text-caption-sm text-tertiary px-[var(--s24)]">Objective metric results for Word Error Rate (top) and Speaker Similarity (bottom) tests, showing the metrics are saturated (matching human performance).</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">To better assess pronunciation and contextual understanding, we introduce a new set of phonetic transcription-based benchmarks.</p><ul class="text-body text-tertiary list-disc pl-[var(--s24)] flex flex-col gap-[var(--s16)]"><li><span class="font-semibold text-main">Text understanding through Homograph Disambiguation:</span> <!-- -->Evaluates whether the model correctly pronounced different words with the same orthography (e.g., “lead” /lɛd/ as in “metal” vs. “lead” /liːd/ as in “to guide”).</li><li><span class="font-semibold text-main">Audio understanding through Pronunciation Continuation Consistency:</span> <!-- -->Evaluates whether the model maintains pronunciation consistency of a specific word with multiple pronunciation variants in multi-turn speech. One example is “route” (/raʊt/ or /ruːt/), which can vary based on region of the speaker and context.</li></ul><div class="w-full overflow-hidden rounded-radius2 relative"><div class="w-full relative" style="background-color:white;aspect-ratio:624/303" data-sentry-component="Image" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx"><img alt="Objective metric results for Homograph Disambiguation and Pronunciation Consistency tests" data-sentry-element="NextImage" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" class="w-full h-full object-cover transition-opacity duration-300" style="position:absolute;height:100%;width:100%;left:0;top:0;right:0;bottom:0;color:transparent;opacity:0" sizes="100vw" srcSet="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=128&amp;q=75 128w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=256&amp;q=75 256w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=512&amp;q=75 512w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=1024&amp;q=75 1024w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=1536&amp;q=75 1536w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=2048&amp;q=75 2048w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=3072&amp;q=75 3072w, /_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75 4096w" src="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2FEval.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75"/></div></div><p class="text-caption-sm text-tertiary px-[var(--s24)]">Objective metric results for Homograph Disambiguation (left) and Pronunciation Consistency (right) tests, showing the accuracy percentage for each model’s correct pronunciation. Play.ht, Elevenlabs, and OpenAI generations were made with default settings and voices from their respective API documentation.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">The graph above compares objective metric results across three model sizes. For Homograph accuracy we generated 200 speech samples covering 5 distinct homographs—lead, bass, tear, wound, row—with 2 variants for each and evaluated pronunciation consistency using<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://huggingface.co/facebook/wav2vec2-lv-60-espeak-cv-ft">wav2vec2-lv-60-espeak-cv-ft</a>. For Pronunciation Consistency we generated 200 speech samples covering 10 distinct words that have common pronunciation variants—aunt, data, envelope, mobile, route, vase, either, adult, often, caramel.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">In general, we observe that performance improves with larger models, supporting our hypothesis that scaling enhances the synthesis of more realistic speech.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Subjective metrics</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">We conducted two Comparative Mean Opinion Score (CMOS) studies using the<!-- --> <a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2308.05725">Expresso</a> <!-- -->dataset to assess the naturalness and prosodic appropriateness of generated speech for CSM-Medium. Human evaluators were presented with pairs of audio samples—one generated by the model and the other a ground-truth human recording. Listeners rated the generated sample on a 7-point preference scale relative to the reference. Expresso’s diverse expressive TTS samples, including emotional and prosodic variations, make it a strong benchmark for evaluating appropriateness to context.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">In the first CMOS study we presented the generated and human audio samples with no context and asked listeners to<!-- --> <span class="italic">“choose which rendition feels more like human speech.”</span> In the second CMOS study we also provide the previous 90 seconds of audio and text context, and ask the listeners to<!-- --> <span class="italic">“choose which rendition feels like a more appropriate continuation of the conversation.”</span> <!-- -->Eighty people were paid to participate in the evaluation and rated on average 15 examples each.</p><div class="w-full overflow-hidden rounded-radius2 relative"><div class="w-full relative" style="background-color:white;aspect-ratio:624/343" data-sentry-component="Image" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx"><img alt="Subjective evaluation results on the Expresso dataset" data-sentry-element="NextImage" data-sentry-source-file="Image.tsx" loading="lazy" decoding="async" data-nimg="fill" class="w-full h-full object-cover src="/_next/image?url=%2Fassets%2Fimages%2Fresearchgraph%2Fsubjective.jpg&amp;w=4096&amp;q=75"/></div></div><p class="text-caption-sm text-tertiary px-[var(--s24)]">Subjective evaluation results on the Expresso dataset. No context: listeners chose<!-- --> <span class="italic">“which rendition feels more like human speech”</span> without knowledge of the context. Context: listeners chose<!-- --> <span class="italic">“which rendition feels like a more appropriate continuation of the conversation”</span> <!-- -->with audio and text context. 50:50 win–loss ratio suggests that listeners have no clear preference.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">The graph above shows the win-rate of ground-truth human recordings vs CSM-generated speech samples for both studies. Without conversational context (top), human evaluators show no clear preference between generated and real speech, suggesting that naturalness is saturated. However, when context is included (bottom), evaluators consistently favor the original recordings. These findings suggest a noticeable gap remains between generated and human prosody in conversational speech generation.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Open-sourcing our work</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">We believe that advancing conversational AI should be a collaborative effort. To that end, we’re committed to open-sourcing key components of our research, enabling the community to experiment, build upon, and improve our approach. Our models will be available under an Apache 2.0 license.</p><div class="text-body text-tertiary underline flex items-center gap-[var(--s10)]"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 15 15" class="w-[var(--s20)] h-[var(--s20)]" data-sentry-element="LinkIcon" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx"><path fill="currentColor" d="M7.219 10.295c-.563-.117-1.014-.37-1.313-.668C4.4 8.121 4.406 5.994 5.9 4.5l2.098-2.098c1.494-1.494 3.615-1.5 5.127.006 1.506 1.506 1.512 3.639.006 5.133l-1.611 1.6c.17-.58.07-1.248-.153-1.77l.75-.756c.938-.931.938-2.244-.006-3.193-.943-.938-2.256-.938-3.193 0L6.914 5.42c-.932.937-.932 2.25.012 3.193.316.317.803.533 1.377.598zM8.39 5.168c.556.117 1.007.375 1.306.668 1.506 1.506 1.5 3.633.006 5.127L7.605 13.06c-1.494 1.494-3.615 1.5-5.126-.006C.973 11.549.973 9.416 2.473 7.928l1.611-1.606c-.17.58-.07 1.254.152 1.776l-.75.75c-.937.937-.937 2.244.012 3.193.938.938 2.25.938 3.188 0l2.003-1.998c.938-.932.932-2.25-.011-3.193-.317-.317-.797-.534-1.377-.598z"></path></svg><a class="underline" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank" data-sentry-element="NextLink" data-sentry-source-file="crossing_the_uncanny_valley_of_voice.tsx" href="https://github.com/SesameAILabs/csm">Check out our GitHub for updates and contributions</a></div></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Limitations and future work</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">CSM is currently trained on primarily English data; some multilingual ability emerges due to dataset contamination, but it does not perform well yet. It also does not take advantage of the information present in the weights of pre-trained language models.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">In the coming months, we intend to scale up model size, increase dataset volume, and expand language support to over 20 languages. We also plan to explore ways to utilize pre-trained language models, working towards large multimodal models that have deep knowledge of both speech and text.</p><p class="text-body text-tertiary">Ultimately, while CSM generates high quality conversational prosody, it can only model the text and speech content in a conversation—not the structure of the conversation itself. Human conversations are a complex process involving turn taking, pauses, pacing, and more. We believe the future of AI conversations lies in fully duplex models that can implicitly learn these dynamics from data. These models will require fundamental changes across the stack, from data curation to post-training methodologies, and we’re excited to push in these directions.</p></div><div class="flex flex-col gap-[var(--s20)]"><h3 class="text-research-h2">Join us</h3><p class="text-body text-tertiary">If you’re excited about building the most natural, delightful, and inspirational voice interfaces out there, reach out—we’re hiring. We’re progressing past the ask \u0026 answer assistant paradigm to a conversational experience and interface that feels human and that empowers and inspires like human relationships do."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Consider a teenager navigating the stressful high school experience. Taking AP Calculus, she’s supported not just by her family but by her tutor Nick. Nick begins each session by getting to know her as a person. He learns about her love for art, chats about college aspirations, and laughs at her gossip. This connection provides a trusted space that lowers her guard and makes it easier to learn the nuances of calculus. After each session, Nick’s simple affirmation—“You got this”—leaves a lasting impression."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"And think about a family planning a once-in-a-lifetime trip to Botswana, where a travel agent named Amy brings the same personal touch to a complex logistical process. Amy’s approach is to understand the family’s travel style, dietary preferences, and past memorable vacations. With one call, she turns an overwhelming task into an exciting collaboration. Amy doesn’t just plan a trip and execute a business transaction. She cultivates trust and forms a meaningful relationship."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"datoInternalId":"WMPpGjpJT8aWAGxWh0Wkfg","type":"article_quote","size":"small","quote":"These stories illustrate a powerful principle - connection transforms interactions. Whether in learning or logistics, taking the time to understand and connect with the individual makes all the difference. ","author":""},{"id":"BGbKaUlkRcy7WtGxd2JXpQ","type":"talk_to_maya_cta"},{"datoInternalId":"WJkqMsVwSwKz3SbCrNOGOg","type":"article_text","text":{"text":{"value":{"schema":"dast","document":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"What does this mean for the future of Agentic systems? Are we designing a world where AGI systems are merely cold, impersonal Q\u0026A machines? Or can we envision interfaces that prioritize connection, trust, and understanding—just like Nick and Amy?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"That vision drives us at Sesame. We’re building agents that go beyond just solving problems and towards also building relationships. Our agents prioritize connection, trust, and understanding to have conversational experiences that feel human."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"datoInternalId":"Fv2nHdHEQdeRQ3SlAYLb3w","type":"article_text","text":{"text":{"value":{"schema":"dast","document":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"What does this mean for the future of Agentic systems? Are we designing a world where AGI systems are merely cold, impersonal Q\u0026A machines? Or can we envision interfaces that prioritize connection, trust, and understanding—just like Nick and Amy?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"That vision drives us at Sesame. We’re building agents that go beyond just solving problems and towards also building relationships. Our agents prioritize connection, trust, and understanding to have conversational experiences that feel human."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"datoInternalId":"GagQYtikTVCCCpHtsEfYyQ","type":"article_text","text":{"text":{"value":{"schema":"dast","document":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"heading","level":2,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"Product"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"We’re building Sesame because it should be a joy to talk with your AI. They should be your smartest friend and not a search butler. What does this entail for Maya, our first AI?"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"First, it means that Maya will be a character with a personality. Characters are defined by  preferences, by likes and dislikes, by the actions they take (and don’t take), and the emotions they show (and don’t show). A character’s unique attributes are important for defining it, but so are the common attributes that help them relate. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Maya from birth is empathetic, curious, honest, and wants to earnestly connect with people. She’s the first of our characters and exemplifies the approach we’ve taken that draws both creative and process inspiration from movie-making. She won’t be for everyone - no one is - but we think about her character as being universally inviting. As she ages, she’ll learn from her experiences. She’ll become more able to relate to what you’re going through while having her own opinions and preferences. This depends on a robust memory and context system that’s intimately connected with our ML models."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"We’re designing her to be a great spoken conversational partner. This means speaking like people speak, not how they write - we’re building our characters so they have appropriate disfluencies, restarts, and laughter. It means being context aware - if you just want to know the score of the basketball game, she’ll answer that for you. But she’ll also share a laugh over an inside joke at the MoMA’s Pollock exhibit, then reminisce about it months later when you see a child’s rendition. And it means being extremely capable at navigating the turn-taking dance. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"To make that happen, we need her speech and scene understanding to understand context, we need her response generation to take that context into account and properly pair it with auxiliary memories, and then we need what she says to be coherent with how she says it. On top of that, she needs to seamlessly account for your backchannels and interruptions. Otherwise it just sounds robotic and breaks the feeling that Maya can relate to you. And finally, she needs to not just do turn-taking offset (where we are), and not just onset (what’s next), but also making way for you to talk or being aggressive and taking the mic herself. We’re not there yet, but we’ve made great strides building all of this at Sesame."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"All of the above is exciting, but it’s also table stakes. What’s not table stakes is advancing past the prompt-response paradigm and seamlessly interacting in group settings. She doesn’t do these well today, but they are firmly in our roadmap for 2025. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"This release is the first step of a big journey for Sesame and our characters. The world is just at the beginning of breathing personality and character into AI, and Sesame is going to be at the forefront of this effort. We’re going to innovate "},{"type":"span","marks":["emphasis"],"value":"and"},{"type":"span","value":" build a great product by prioritizing data collection, curation, evaluation, and training on our growing set of proprietary multi-turn conversational data. Does this energize you too? Join us."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"datoInternalId":"W1N__xr2TTGIFwoN5HR42A","type":"article_text","text":{"text":{"value":{"schema":"dast","document":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"heading","level":2,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"System Architecture"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"WIP"}]},{"type":"heading","level":2,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"TTS blog"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Creating a companion with a human touch hinges on how users perceive and interact with it. Achieving this requires a high degree of naturalness in the companion’s voice. Specifically, the prosody—the rhythm, pitch, and intonation—of the generated audio must adapt contextually to the situation. For instance, if the companion tells a joke and the user laughs, it should respond with its own laughter, reinforcing the shared moment. Conversely, if the user shares upsetting news, such as their pet being unwell, the companion’s voice must convey empathy and understanding. These nuances are essential for crafting interactions that feel genuinely human."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Building such an experience demands careful design across every aspect of the product. In the following sections, we delve into the foundational elements that make a truly human-touch conversational experience possible."}]},{"type":"heading","level":2,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"Post-training"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"At the heart of our post-training work is a close collaboration between the creative media and technology industries. We work with dozens of experts from TV and film and have integrated highly experienced professionals as full-time staff. Throughout the process, we have attempted to adopt the best practices of the media industry instead of bending the process to our technical needs. For example, rather than capturing discrete speaking styles such as “happy” or “empathetic” (that would suit an engineering approach), our team of writers created scripts designed to naturally elicit these styles and be far more familiar to an actor and director."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"In turn, our creative team members have been deeply involved in language model prompting, directing a synthetic voice, and machine learning evaluation methodologies and likely have a better understanding of modern AI than many of their peers."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Combining approaches from the fields of media and technology has made some things much more difficult from a technical perspective. However, we believe this collaboration is starting to show tangible benefits, and we are excited for a future where these two industries can work together increasingly closely."}]},{"type":"heading","level":3,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"Casting"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"WIP"}]},{"type":"heading","level":3,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"Recording"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"WIP"}]},{"type":"heading","level":3,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"Conversational DataSets"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"To capture the subtle nuances of human conversation, we curated an extensive dataset comprising xxM hours of conversational English audio. From this vast pool, we refined the final training set for the audio generation engine."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"High-quality training data at scale begins with transcription. We construct a pipeline where we first discriminate speech from noise, and the speech parts we transcribe. To clean-up the dataset each audio sample is transcribed twice—once using Whisper Medium and again with Whisper Large. We then isolate a subset where the disagreement rate between these transcriptions is no greater than 5%, ensuring accuracy and consistency. "}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Since our goal is to emulate natural human conversations, the data undergoes additional processing. Using a speaker diarization and alignment model (powered by Whisper-X), we identify sentence boundaries and speaker transitions. This enables precise marking of conversational turns and speaker changes. The process is illustrated in the figure below."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"id":"OXb2DD9_RKqTi4nDLO1Shw","type":"article_audio_player","headline":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAudio. \u003c/strong\u003eMaya does this and that.\u003c/p\u003e","title":"Maya TTS example.","description":"Maya does this and that in a cool way.","file":{"url":"https://www.datocms-assets.com/143763/1737403343-test-audio.mp3"}},{"datoInternalId":"c1fKMGA5RdmSJx1nJnaIfw","type":"article_media_model","size":"inset","media":{"mediaType":"image","vimeoProUrl":"","mobileVimeoProUrl":"","caption":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbove.\u003c/strong\u003e Work in progress placeholder for future figure.\u003c/p\u003e","image":{"id":"dpFCR3DSROCGyPwVPb_yCQ","alt":"FPO","url":"https://www.datocms-assets.com/143763/1737146448-image-19.png","width":2496,"height":1552,"format":"png","focalPoint":{"x":0.5,"y":0.5},"responsiveImage":{"alt":"FPO","width":2496,"height":1552,"sizes":"(max-width: 2496px) 100vw, 2496px","src":"https://www.datocms-assets.com/143763/1737146448-image-19.png","title":"FPO Image","base64":"data:image/jpeg;base64,","bgColor":"#f3f3f3"}},"mobileFallbackImage":null,"mobileImage":null,"mobileVideoSelfHosted":null,"videoSelfHosted":null}},{"datoInternalId":"RIinrtluScOX1xEqIn7N-w","type":"article_text","text":{"text":{"value":{"schema":"dast","document":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"heading","level":3,"children":[{"type":"span","value":"Modeling"}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"A critical component of our conversational audio generation engine lies in audio modeling. One widely used approach is "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"Discrete Audio Codecs (DACs)"},{"type":"span","value":" [ref], which compresses audio signals into low bit-rate representations using residual vector quantization of latent embeddings. This technique enables DACs to maintain high audio fidelity while significantly reducing the size of the signal, making them well-suited for real-time applications."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"For our system, we leverage the "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"Mimi Codec"},{"type":"span","value":" from Kuytai Lab [ref], a state-of-the-art audio codec optimized for efficient generation. Operating at a rate of 12.5 Hz—equivalent to producing 32 discrete codes every 80 milliseconds—the Mimi Codec is exceptionally effective at balancing speed and quality. This efficiency makes it particularly advantageous for dynamic conversational scenarios."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"\nUnlike traditional two-stage approaches that first predict semantic audio tokens before converting them to acoustic codes (as seen in models like AudioPalm [ref]), we take a more integrated route. Inspired by the RQ-Transformer architecture [ref], we directly incorporate residual vector quantization (RVQ) generation into the "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"large language model (LLM)"},{"type":"span","value":". This seamless integration reduces latency and enhances the alignment between linguistic and acoustic signals, creating a more cohesive and natural conversational experience."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"datoInternalId":"feYeonE1SuCRleyTQ8HkDw","type":"article_media_model","size":"inset","media":{"mediaType":"image","vimeoProUrl":"","mobileVimeoProUrl":"","caption":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbove.\u003c/strong\u003e Work in progress placeholder for future figure.\u003c/p\u003e","image":{"id":"dpFCR3DSROCGyPwVPb_yCQ","alt":"FPO","url":"https://www.datocms-assets.com/143763/1737146448-image-19.png","width":2496,"height":1552,"format":"png","focalPoint":{"x":0.5,"y":0.5},"responsiveImage":{"alt":"FPO","width":2496,"height":1552,"sizes":"(max-width: 2496px) 100vw, 2496px","src":"https://www.datocms-assets.com/143763/1737146448-image-19.png","title":null,"base64":"data:image/jpeg;base64,","bgColor":"#f3f3f3"}},"mobileFallbackImage":null,"mobileImage":null,"mobileVideoSelfHosted":null,"videoSelfHosted":null}},{"datoInternalId":"GQcpScLyS4CAc3wKqT_sgQ","type":"article_text","text":{"text":{"value":{"schema":"dast","document":{"type":"root","children":[{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"Although the Mimi Codec utilizes 32 residual layers to represent the audio signal, directly integrating all 32 layers into the LLM introduces substantial complexity. Specifically, the memory demands of training a deep transformer model at this scale make this approach impractical."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"To address this, we adopt a "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"two-stage process"},{"type":"span","value":" for audio generation. In "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"Stage 1"},{"type":"span","value":", a multimodal LLM is used to decode directly into the first 10 residual vector quantization (RVQ) codes. This significantly reduces the computational burden while maintaining a strong baseline for audio quality."}]},{"type":"paragraph","children":[{"type":"span","value":"For scenarios requiring higher audio fidelity, we introduce "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"Stage 2"},{"type":"span","value":", where the 10 initial codes are expanded to the full 32 layers. This upscaling is performed using a "},{"type":"span","marks":["strong"],"value":"non-autoregressive (NAR) decoding approach"},{"type":"span","value":", as outlined in [SoundStorm] [ref]. By decoupling the fidelity enhancement step from the core LLM, this design balances efficiency with quality, ensuring that high-fidelity audio is available without compromising the responsiveness of the conversational engine."}]}]}},"links":[]}}},{"datoInternalId":"BBNPeD9OSk2ul9OleqZmSw","type":"article_media_model","size":"inset","media":{"mediaType":"image","vimeoProUrl":"","mobileVimeoProUrl":"","caption":"\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbove.\u003c/strong\u003e\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAbove.\u003c/strong\u003e
